awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Evolutionary and developmental influences on skeletal maturation and internal structure
awd_abstract_narration:
The shape of the skeleton for a given species reflects both developmental genetic processes dictated by genes and environmental influences resulting from life history. In studies of primates and humans, understanding the relative contributions of these processes can help in making inferences about behavior and relatedness among both living and extinct species. For example, in humans, the enlarged calcaneus, or heel bone, with its expanded trabecular (spongy) bone volume is a well-known adaptation associated with walking upright. In contrast, the dramatic reduction of the pisiform bone in the in human wrist compared to other primates is not well appreciated. The fact that these are the only bones of the wrist and ankle to form growth plates suggests that they are under similar developmental control despite their different functional demands in humans. As such these bones form an ideal model to determine differential effects of genetic patterning and life history on skeletal shape. Increased knowledge of how differences in skeletal growth affect bone shape may also improve our understanding of the etiology of skeletal disease.  This work will be used to train a female graduate student and several undergraduates, and will also be the basis of several K-12 student and educator outreach programs throughout central Pennsylvania. 

Functional morphological studies of the calcaneus, and specifically its trabecular bone structure, are abundant given its critical role in the unique forms of locomotion observed in hominoids, but little is known about how development influences trabecular structure. This study will investigate how trabecular structure changes when growth is altered by mutations in developmental genes. A comparative study of pisiform and calcaneus ossification across anthropoid primates and a mouse outgroup will be used to assess degree of developmental integration between the fore and hind limbs. Developmental effects of growth plate structure on trabecular bone will be studied using CT scans of calcanei from mice with normal growth plates and Hox11 loss-of-function mice with known growth plate abnormalities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The human pisiform bone of the wrist is uniquely short compared to other mammals, including primates. The comparable structure in the ankle, the calcaneus (or heel bone), is enlarged in humans when compared to other primates. In most mammals, each of these bones develop a growth plate separating primary and secondary ossification centers; however, the short human pisiform only develops from one ossification center. We compared the timing of pisiform and calcaneus formation and conclude that the human pisiform is short because it has lost the primary ossification center and the associated growth plate, thus only retaining the secondary ossification center. Therefore, this project was able to determine the developmental mechanism (ossification center and growth plate loss) underlying a unique human trait (short pisiform).

Mice with mutations to Hoxa11 and Hoxd11 genes have various changes in skeletal morphology and growth plate structure, including shortened pisiforms and irregular growth plates. This project has allowed us to amass a sample of juvenile and adult mice with Hoxa11 and Hoxd11 mutations. High resolution CT scans of these mice will allow us to better understand the influence of these genes on variability in skeletal ossification, bone shapes and internal structure. These analyses are ongoing and will improve our understanding of the relationship between genes, behavior, and bone shape and structure, and potentially the genetic mechanisms underlying human pisiform reduction. Additionally, these data increase our understanding of general bone biology, bone growth, and may improve our understanding of skeletal diseases.

This project was used to train a female Ph.D. student and several undergraduates in multiple research methods in the areas of developmental biology, comparative anatomy, and 3D imaging. Results from this project will be included in upcoming outreach programs with a local museum for high school students underserved by traditional STEM education and courses for professional health students. 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2017
Modified by: Kelsey Kjosness
